**ChatGPT Launches Memory Feature to Retrieve Information from Past Conversations**
OpenAI has introduced a new memory feature for ChatGPT that enables users to retrieve information from previous conversations with greater accuracy. This functionality is currently available to users on the Pro and Plus subscription plans worldwide. According to OpenAI’s official blog, the update allows ChatGPT to locate specific details across a user’s chat history, eliminating the need to manually search through old conversations. 'Any prior chat used to answer your question now appears as a source so you can open and review the original context,' OpenAI emphasized. Additionally, the company announced plans to introduce ads in the free and Go subscription tiers, starting in the United States. Ads will be displayed at the end of responses, clearly labeled and separated from content. OpenAI confirmed that responses will never be based on advertising and that user data and conversation history will remain protected and not sold to advertisers. The company stated that ads are 'useful, entertaining, and help people discover new products and services.' Ads will not appear for users under 18, and no advertising will be shown for sensitive or regulated topics such as health, mental health, or politics. Users will also have access to information explaining why they are seeing a particular ad.

**ChatGPT Health**
OpenAI launched ChatGPT Health on January 7, 2026, amid growing demand, with TechCrunch reporting that 230 million people are asking health-related questions to ChatGPT weekly. Seven out of ten health conversations occur outside regular clinic hours, indicating a clear gap in access to medical advice. Despite OpenAI acknowledging that ChatGPT Health is not HIPAA-compliant and is not intended for diagnosis, the product was released due to existing user demand. ECRI, a patient safety organization, has identified AI chatbot misuse as the top health technology hazard for 2026, citing cases where chatbots provided incorrect diagnoses and even invented non-existent body parts while sounding authoritative. This highlights a strategic shift: AI adoption in healthcare is no longer a question of 'if' but 'how,' as users are already relying on these tools, making it imperative for businesses to manage risk while capturing value. The article questions whether the pace of AI integration in healthcare is too fast or simply responsive to user needs.

**Shopping Cart to Be Added to ChatGPT Interface**
OpenAI plans to integrate an online shopping cart into the ChatGPT interface to advance its monetization strategy, as the company is projected to reach profitability only by 2029 given current costs. The update will allow users to browse product details, select delivery addresses and payment methods, and complete purchases directly within the chatbot interface. Users will be able to add items to a saved cart for later purchase and sort products by criteria. Microsoft has already implemented similar e-commerce integration in its Copilot feature, prompting OpenAI to likely follow suit soon. Additionally, merchants can submit product descriptions to be used in AI-generated recommendations. Personalized responses based on prior chat history will be available during sessions, though conversations will not be permanently stored. The exact rollout timeline is unspecified, but OpenAI is expected to act quickly due to strong market competition.

**OpenAI Launches Translation-Optimized 'ChatGPT Translate'; Microsoft Unveils Copilot Keyboard with Dictionary and Customization Features**
OpenAI has released a new translation-focused tool called 'ChatGPT Translate,' available for free to all users. Unlike the standard ChatGPT, which requires prompt-based translation, ChatGPT Translate operates like a traditional web translator: users input text on the left, and the translated output appears on the right. The tool automatically detects the source language and offers advanced text refinement options, including 'natural-sounding output,' 'formal business tone,' 'explanation for children,' and 'academic or expert-level phrasing.' Additionally, Microsoft has introduced a new IME (Input Method Editor) called 'Copilot Keyboard,' announced on January 20, 2026, with plans for monthly updates. Initially launched in beta in October 2025, Copilot Keyboard integrates with Copilot and includes features such as up-to-date vocabulary (including trending terms, names, places, and new brands), 'Copilot Search' for on-the-fly word lookup, customizable themes, and a desktop display of the Copilot character. The tool now includes previously unavailable features like a built-in dictionary and keyboard customization. Microsoft confirms that input entered via Copilot Keyboard is not read by, stored in, or used for AI training purposes.

**From Dreaming of the Stars to Walking on the Ground: ChatGPT to Introduce Ads Amid Monetization Pressure**
OpenAI has announced plans to introduce ads into the free version and the entry-level 'Go' subscription tier of ChatGPT, with testing set to begin in the coming weeks for users in the United States. The move is driven by the need to offset high infrastructure and energy costs, as OpenAI's CFO revealed that the company's revenue growth over the past year was fueled by a 9.5-fold increase in compute costs, despite its Annual Recurring Revenue (ARR) surpassing $20 billion. While OpenAI claims ads will not compromise answer objectivity, will not use user data for ad targeting, and will allow users to disable personalized ads, concerns remain about the long-term implications. CEO Sam Altman, who previously opposed advertising in AI, now describes it as 'a valuable exploration for users.' Critics, including DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis, argue that AI assistants are fundamentally different from search engines: they are personal, trusted companions, and intrusive ads could erode user trust and undermine the perceived authenticity of interactions. The 'Memory' feature, which allows ChatGPT to recall user details for personalized responses, raises privacy concerns, as it could enable hyper-targeted advertising. Despite OpenAI's current restraint, the history of digital advertising—from banners to invasive in-app ads—suggests that user tolerance may erode over time. With only 5% of weekly active users paying for ChatGPT, the remaining 95% of free users are seen as cost centers. Ads offer a way to monetize this large base, transforming them from liabilities into revenue sources. However, this shift risks alienating users who view AI not as a tool but as a confidant or even a friend, especially among vulnerable groups like minors who rely on AI for emotional support.

**OpenAI Says It Is Bringing Ads to ChatGPT**
OpenAI announced on January 23, 2026, that it will begin testing advertisements within the Free and Go tiers of ChatGPT in the 'coming weeks,' marking a major shift toward traditional monetization for the world’s most popular AI chatbot. Ads will appear at the bottom of ChatGPT responses when a relevant sponsored product or service aligns with the conversation, and will be 'clearly labeled and separated from organic answers.' They will not appear for users under 18 or near 'sensitive or regulated' topics such as health, mental health, or politics. Users on the Plus, Pro, Business, and Enterprise plans will remain ad-free. OpenAI emphasized that ads will not influence ChatGPT’s responses, conversations will remain private from advertisers, and ad placements will always be distinct from core content. The company envisions future conversational ad experiences—such as asking follow-up questions about a recommended product while seeking a recipe—making ads more interactive and relevant. This move follows OpenAI’s expansion of its marketing infrastructure, including hiring Fidji Simo as CEO of applications and building a ChatGPT Growth team with engineers focused on ad platform integration, campaign management, and real-time attribution. The decision comes amid pressure from competitors like Google and Anthropic, and a reported 'code red' internal memo from CEO Sam Altman in December 2025. With over 800 million weekly active users, OpenAI is now testing ads as a key monetization strategy after relying primarily on subscriptions and enterprise deals. Advertisers will likely assess engagement in conversational contexts, but OpenAI faces the challenge of maintaining user trust while introducing ads into an experience historically valued as ad-free.

OpenAI has launched ChatGPT Atlas, a new web browser designed to function as a 'super-assistant' by understanding users' online activities and helping complete tasks without switching tabs or copying and pasting. The browser features a split-screen layout with the user's webpage on one side and ChatGPT on the other, enabling real-time summarization and explanation of content. It includes built-in ChatGPT memory, 'agent mode' for limited automated actions such as researching topics, booking appointments, or summarizing websites, and the ability to recall context, revisit past pages, and act based on browsing history. Users can manage and delete saved history at any time, and by default, OpenAI does not use browsing content for training unless users opt in. Atlas cannot run code, download files, install extensions, or access other apps, and it pauses on private sites like banking platforms. The browser is currently available on macOS worldwide, with versions for Windows, iOS, and Android forthcoming. OpenAI's move positions it to directly compete with Google’s Gemini-integrated Chrome and startups like Perplexity, which launched its own AI browser earlier in 2025.

**ChatGPT Atlas browser by OpenAI: Release date, platforms and how you can download it easily**
ChatGPT Atlas, an AI-powered web browser developed by OpenAI, was released globally on macOS on October 21, 2025, for Free, Plus, Pro, and Go users, with Business, Enterprise, and Edu users gaining access if enabled by their administrators. The browser features a ChatGPT sidebar for summarizing content, comparing products, analyzing data, and answering questions; Agent Mode for completing tasks end-to-end such as event planning or online shopping; and Browser Memory, which allows users to recall browsing context and past chats—such as 'Summarize the job postings I viewed last week'—with privacy controls, including the ability to browse logged out, clear history, and manage memories. Agent Mode does not run code, download files, or access other apps, and sensitive actions like logging into financial accounts require explicit user approval. OpenAI advises caution when using Agent Mode to prevent unintended or malicious behavior. Future updates are expected to include multi-profile support, enhanced developer tools, and improved app integration. Versions for Windows, iOS, and Android are forthcoming. Users can download ChatGPT Atlas from chatgpt.com/atlas and import bookmarks, passwords, and browsing history from their current browser, according to Reuters. The launch positions ChatGPT Atlas as a competitor to browsers like Google Chrome, Perplexity’s Comet, and Opera’s Neon.

**OpenAI Launches AI Browser ChatGPT Atlas**
OpenAI has launched ChatGPT Atlas, a web browser that integrates ChatGPT directly into everyday browsing tasks, with a global release for macOS today available to Free, Plus, Pro, and Go users. Windows, iOS, and Android versions are planned for future release. Atlas embeds ChatGPT in the new-tab experience to handle queries, search, and inline writing without requiring tab switching. It leverages context from users’ web history, currently open pages, and logged-in sites to personalize responses. The browser remembers details from prior sessions to resurface pages, automate repetitive tasks, and continue unfinished work. Users can issue natural-language commands—such as 'reopen tabs from yesterday' or 'clean up open tabs'—which Atlas executes natively. OpenAI is also previewing an agent mode that allows ChatGPT to perform actions on behalf of users within the browser; access is restricted to Plus, Pro, and Business tiers during the preview. Privacy is emphasized: browsing history can be cleared, incognito mode is available, and browser memory is opt-in and fully manageable by users. OpenAI stated that it does not use browsing content to train its models by default. The product is positioned as part of a broader initiative toward a context-aware assistant for research, shopping, planning, work, and learning. Additional information, including availability, use cases, safety details, and a product blog, is available in OpenAI’s press materials.
